field_edited_text.value:
CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS 163

Shores are inadequate as connections of the highways of the State, separated
by the Chesapeake Bay, when measured in the terms of modern rapid trans-
portation afforded by the automobile and modern highways.

(2) The geographical location of the Sandy Point-Kent Island Site
makes the distance from Baltimore to the majority of the county seats on
the Eastern Shore of Maryland shorter than when a connection by way of
Millers Island and Tolchester is considered.

(3) A bridge at the Sandy Point-Kent Island Site will serve more people
than a bridge at the Millers Island-Tolchester Site, because, in addition to
being quite as accessible for the metropolitan area of Baltimore, as is the
Millers Island Site, it is in closer proximity to Annapolis and Wash-
ington.

(4) The bridge at Millers Island is longer than the bridge at Sandy
Point, although its construction cost is less. The alignment of the highway,
of which the Millers Island Bridge would become a part, is indirect, since
it is necessary to travel north from the Patapsco River Neck across Hart and
Millers Islands before crossing the Bay, and for traffic between Baltimore
and the Lower Eastern Shore, a similar distance south on the Eastern Shore
1s necessary, thus increasing the distance between Baltimore and Centerville
or Wye Mills over the distance which it would be necessary to travel if the
location of this bridge were shifted south to connect Patapsco River Neck
with the Eastern Shore direct at a point between Tolchester and Rock
Hall.

(6) The War Department has required a lateral clearance of 1000 feet
and a vertical clearance of 140 feet over the east channel near Tolchester,
as compared to 1200 feet lateral clearance and 175 feet vertical clearance
required near Sandy Point. These requirements recognize the greater
importance of the channel between Baltimore and the Virginia capes, as
compared with the channel between Baltimore and the C & D Canal. The
War Department has, however, required that a secondary long span be
placed over the west channel of the Bay, between Millers Island and
Tolchester and has indicated the probable necessity for a movable span in
the crossing between Patapsco River Neck and Hart Island.

(6) Although the water depths between Sandy Point and Kent Island
are considerably greater than the depths between Millers Island and Tol-
chester, the heavy sand stratum underlying the Sandy Point Site, for the
entire width of the Bay, makes the foundation conditions at this site better
than the water depths would indicate, and the foundation conditions at the
site of the main channel span at Sandy Point are considerably better than
